regarding tariffs, the economic stakes are massive. the u.s. and china trade about $700 billion worth of goods annually, including key exports like smartphones, laptops, soybeans, and gas turbines. without a deal to de-escalate tensions, higher tariffs will likely disrupt supply chains, raise consumer prices, and strain already fragile global markets. this will be the first real increase in tariffs under the current monetary regime, and the first major departure of the united states from neo-liberal trade policy to mercantilism in most of our lifetimes. the last material increase in us tariffs was with the smoot-hawley tariff act in 1930, and at that time the us dollar was on the gold standard and keynes had yet to publish his general theory. global trade as % of gdp has been steadily rising for decades as most trade barriers have fallen, bringing the broad global gains from trade between countries with differing specializations, but at the cost of self-sufficiency, the focus of the current administration. sheltering national industries, either through tariffs or capital controls, is not an uncommon strategy in developing countries, but with varying results: broad success in chinaâ€™s case and numerous failures in latin america. it is a less common strategy from a leading developed country and is broadly a sign of weakness, not strength. if the usâ€™ industries were competitive or innovative enough, they wouldnâ€™t need the governmentâ€™s help to keep them on their feet. this is not to brush aside criticism of other countriesâ€™ unfair policies that put the united states at a disadvantage, such as china dumping solar panels on the us, but we have broadly abandoned the global rules-based infrastructure we helped build to resolve them in an ordered way, in favor of blanket tariffs and bilateral diplomacy. furthermore, trade imbalances are a direct result of the triffin dilemma, a concept identified in the 1960s by economist robbert triffin, which postulates that the country with the global reserve currency must become a net-exporter of their national currency, naturally resulting in a trade deficit. imposing tariffs on exporters to the united states, who themselves â€œbuyâ€ dollars when they sell goods to us, makes it harder to export dollars and thus could jeopardize the global reserve status of the u.s. dollar. stablecoins can be a powerful countervailing force here, which treasury secretary scott bessent acknowledged at the march 7 crypto roundtable at the white house, in which he said â€œwe are going to keep the u.s. the dominant reserve currency in the world and we are going to use stablecoins to do that.â€ while tariffs and mercantilism may reduce dollar demand from foreign governments or sovereigns, stablecoins can be a force to put dollars directly in the hands of global citizens. can the white house outsmart the triffin dilemma? it seems they plan to try.

there's a loophole (of sorts) in tariffs referred to as "transshipment." in short what this means is - a company can ship their products to an intermediary country, who then ships the products from there to the actually desired location, with the objective of bypassing tariffs on the country of true origin. this can be taken a step further - theoretically, new countries can be "made" simply to circumnavigate tariffs (done through secession/partition). yes tariffs would be placed on these new countries, but likewise, they could just create new countries faster than legislation can go into place. we see something similar with regulation around thc, where new strains were "created" to bypass regulations. would need to do a bit more research, but shared this practices could bypass tariffs, but things do get a bit tricky. other loopholes would be in final assembly. often times there are many products labeled as "made in usa" that are actually manufactured overseas, but final bolts give it this title. wise companies should be searching for some level of loopholes in the interim of building factories in the us. either companies will absorb the impact, or they will pass it onto customers, with 60% of americans living paycheck to paycheck, and 80% of americans in some form of consumer debt. it's gonna hurt.

in signing an agreement and resuming oil exports through the iraq-turkey pipeline deal would lead to the fair distribution of oil revenues among all iraqis a delegation from the kurdistan region is in signing an agreement and resuming oil exports through the iraq-turkey pipeline. for context, the halt in exports has caused significant damage to iraq. since oil production from the kurdistan region is counted within iraqâ€™s opec quota, we have been compensating by cutting production in the southern fields,â€ he added. abdul ghani also voiced hope that a deal would lead to the fair distribution of oil revenues among all iraqis. despite the suspension of exports for more than two years, the kurdistan region continues to produce around 300,000 barrels of oil per day, according to china stops buying liquefied natural gas from the us | malcolm moore, financial times standstill shows how sino-american trade war has spilled into the energy sector chinaâ€™s imports of us liquefied natural gas have completely stopped for more than 10 weeks, according to shipping data showing how the sino-american trade war has spread to energy co-operation. since a 69,000-tonne lng tanker from corpus christi in texas arrived in the southern province of fujian on february 6 there have been no further shipments between the two countries. a second tanker was redirected to bangladesh after it failed to arrive before china imposed a 15 per cent tariff on us lng on february 10. the tariff has since increased to 49 per cent, making us natural gas uneconomic for chinese buyers for the foreseeable future. the freeze on us lng is a repeat of a block on imports that lasted for more than a year during donald trumpâ€™s first term as president. but the impact of the stand-off has potentially far-reaching implications, strengthening chinaâ€™s energy relationship with russia and raising questions over the huge expansion of multibillion-dollar lng terminals that is under way in the us and mexico. â€œthere will be long-term consequences,â€ said anne-sophie corbeau, a natural gas specialist at columbia universityâ€™s center on global energy policy. â€œi do not think chinese lng importers will ever contract any new us lng.â€ since russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of ukraine in 2022, china has imported a relatively low share of its lng from the us, with chinese buyers preferring to resell the fuel into europe for a profit. last year, only 6 per cent of chinaâ€™s lng came from the us, down from a peak of 11 per cent in 2021. however, chinese companies including petrochina and sinopec have signed 13 long-term contracts to buy lng from us terminals, some of which run to 2049, according to data from kpler. such long-term deals were essential for getting huge lng projects off the ground in the us, though corbeau said developers have recently tried to renegotiate terms to take into consideration rising inflation and the costs from us tariffs. gillian boccara, an analyst at kpler, said she saw no reason for trade between the two countries to restart in the short term. â€œthe last time this happened, there was a complete hiatus until the chinese authorities granted waivers to companies, but that was at a time when gas demand was booming,â€ she said. â€œnow we are looking at lower economic growth, and we think the chinese can withstand the loss of these cargoes for quite a long time.â€ chinaâ€™s ambassador to russia said earlier this week that china would probably step up its imports of russian lng instead. â€œi know for sure that there are a lot of buyers. so many buyers are asking the embassy to help establish contacts with russian suppliers, i think there will definitely be more [imports],â€ said zhang hanhui. read more:

iqd rv: trilateral oil meeting held today address critical issues concerning the kurdistan region's oil sector, with a primary focus on resuming oil exports 60-day period to select a consulting firm has expired without consensus absence of agreement, the federal government reserves the right to unilaterally appoint the advisory body erbil (kurdistan24) â€” a trilateral meeting was convened in erbil on sunday among representatives of the iraqi ministry of oil, kurdistan regional government (krg), and the association of the petroleum industry of kurdistan (apikur) to address critical issues concerning the kurdistan region's oil sector, with a primary focus on resuming oil exports. omid sabah, chief of staff of the krg council of ministers, stated that discussions involved the operational activities of oil companies and explored mechanisms to facilitate the restart of exports.the meeting also considered the challenges and proposals presented by these companies to create a conducive environment for resuming oil exports promptly. despite the iraqi parliament's approval of amendments to the federal budget law on february 2, 2025, particularly article 12 concerning the resumption of kurdistan's oil exports, disagreements between the federal government and the krg have hindered the implementation of these provisions. the amendments stipulate that the federal ministry of finance will compensate the krg for production and transportation costs of oil delivered to the state oil marketing organization (somo).an international technical advisory body, to be appointed jointly by the federal and regional governments, was tasked with determining the fair cost of production and transportation for each oil field within 60 days of the law's enactment. however, this deadline has passed without an agreement, prompting concerns from iraqi lawmakers. adnan al-jaberi, deputy chairman of the iraqi parliament's oil and gas committee, emphasized that the 60-day period to select a consulting firm has expired without consensus. he noted that, in the absence of agreement, the federal government reserves the right to unilaterally appoint the advisory body. meanwhile, oil production companies operating in the kurdistan region have expressed skepticism toward the iraqi ministry of oil. these companies demand the settlement of outstanding payments for past production, advance payments, and future guarantees as prerequisites for resuming export operations. the halt in oil exports since march 2023, following a ruling by the international chamber of commerce in paris, has significantly impacted the kurdistan region's economy, leading to delays in public sector salaries and reductions in essential services. baghdad is under increasing pressure to resolve these disputes to restore financial stability and economic growth across iraq. as negotiations continue, the resumption of oil exports remains contingent upon resolving contractual disagreements, ensuring fair compensation for production and transportation costs, and rebuilding trust between the federal government and oil companies operating in the region.

the port of bandar abbas in iran is a significant hub for oil exports, handling a substantial portion of the country's seaborne trade. according to the latest data, bandar abbas is iran's main fuel oil export terminal and plays a crucial role in the country's oil industry. oil export volumes â€¢recent export data: according to the u.s. energy information administration (eia), iran exported an average of 1.4 million barrels per day of crude oil and condensate in 2023, rising to approximately 1.5 million barrels per day during the first eight months of 2024.while this data does not specify the exact volume exported through bandar abbas, it is a significant contributor to iran's total oil exports. â€¢port capacity: bandar abbas handles a substantial portion of iran's oil exports, particularly fuel oil. the port's capacity and infrastructure are designed to support large-scale oil shipments, making it a vital component of iran's energy sector. historical context and recent developments â€¢economic and political significance: the petroleum industry is a cornerstone of iran's economy, accounting for a significant portion of the country's foreign currency earnings. in 2004, iran produced 5.1% of the world's total crude oil, generating revenues of us$25 billion to us$30 billion. the oil and gas sector has been the primary driver of economic growth, directly affecting public development projects, the government's annual budget, and foreign exchange sources. â€¢recent incidents: on april 26, 2025, a massive explosion occurred at the shahid rajaee section of the bandar abbas port, killing at least 28 people and injuring over 800 others. the national iranian oil refining and distribution company (niordc) stated that the explosion was not related to refineries, fuel tanks, or oil pipelines associated with the company in that area. the incident has raised concerns about the safety and security of iran's critical infrastructure, particularly in light of ongoing negotiations with the united states over iran's nuclear program. learn more see sources

'extreme temperature variations in spain' contributed to outage - portuguese grid officialspublished at 07:10 07:10 we have a bit more for you now from the portuguese energy company ren (rede eletrica nacional). it says that "due to extreme temperature variations in the interior or spain, there were anomalous oscillations in the very high voltage lines (400 kv), a phenomenon known as 'induced atmospheric vibration'". erbil, kurdistan region - the kurdistan regionâ€™s council of ministers said on wednesday that it has met its obligations for resuming the regionâ€™s oil exports, calling on the relevant authorities in erbil and baghdad to restart the process â€œas soon as possible.â€ the council of ministers held its weekly meeting in erbil on wednesday to discuss a range of issues, particularly the kurdish oil exports which have been suspended for over two years. â€œthe council of ministers reaffirms its unchanging position in support of negotiations and discussions between both the oil ministry and natural resources ministry for the soonest possible resumption of oil exports,â€ read a statement from the kurdistan regional government (krg). â€œto this end, the council of ministers calls on the [kurdish] ministry of natural resources, the federal oil ministry, oil companies, and [iraqâ€™s state oil marketing organization] somo to continue coordination and negotiation in order to resolve the issues and reach an agreement as soon as possible to resume kurdistan region's oil exports and to prevent further financial losses to the general treasury, which have already exceeded tens of billions of dollars,â€ it added. oil exports from the kurdistan region through the iraq-turkey pipeline have been suspended since march 2023, after a paris-based arbitration court ruled in favor of baghdad, stating that ankara had violated a 1973 pipeline agreement by allowing erbil to export oil independently. iraqâ€™s foreign ministersaidon tuesday that baghdad is seeking to resume kurdish oil exports through the iraq-turkey pipeline and will â€œmake every effortâ€ to do so. myles caggins, spokesperson for the association of the petroleum industry of kurdistan (apikur), an umbrella group of international oil companies operating in the kurdistan region,toldrudaw on tuesday that baghdad must provide written documentation of the international consultantâ€™s audit of production and costs. "i want to make apikurâ€™s position clear. our companies are ready to resume oil exports when we have agreements, and we need agreements for sales and also an agreement for the international consultant that is required by iraq's budget law," he added. in early february, the iraqi parliament approved amendments to the federal budget law, authorizing a $16-per-barrel fee for production and transport costs in the kurdistan region - a move seen as a crucial step toward restarting exports. the amendments also require both the federal government and the krg to establish an international technical consultancy within 60 days to assess production and transportation costs for oil fields in the kurdistan region. if an agreement cannot be reached, the federal council of ministers will appoint the consultancy.

u.s. imposes sweeping tariffs on southeast asian solar panels, drawing concern from asean+3 the united states has introduced a new wave of steep tariffs on solar panel imports from southeast asia, in a move that is deepening trade tensions and triggering alarm across the asia-pacific region. the tariffs - ranging from 34% to a staggering 3,521% -target producers in cambodia, malaysia, thailand, and vietnam, following a year-long investigation prompted by u.s. manufacturersâ€™ complaints of market distortion through cheap, chinese-subsidized solar components. announced by the u.s. department of commerce, the tariffs include both general and company-specific rates: 34.41% on malaysian panels, 375.2% for a producer from thailand, and 395.9% for vietnam. cambodia was hit particularly hard, with general tariffs of 651.85%. two companiesâ€”hounen solar and solar long pv-techâ€”face extraordinary rates as high as 3,521%, effectively pricing them out of the u.s. market. these duties come on top of the existing 10% tariff on most imports and any reciprocal tariffs already in place. the targeted companies represent about 77% of solar module imports into the u.s., according to bloomberg. analysts warn that other nations, including indonesia, india, and laos, may face similar measures later this year, as washington intensifies scrutiny of its green technology supply chains. the move has sparked concern across asia, particularly among southeast asian economies. during the asian development bankâ€™s annual meeting in milan, finance ministers and central bank governors from asean and its dialogue partners - china, japan, and south korea (collectively asean+3) - issued a carefully worded but pointed statement. â€œescalating trade protectionism weighs on global trade, leading to economic fragmentation, affecting trade, investment and capital flows across the region,â€ the asean+3 officials said in their joint communiquÃ©. the statement did not name the united states directly, it reaffirmed the blocâ€™s commitment to â€œa rules-based, free, fair and transparent multilateral trading system.â€ as the global economy becomes increasingly fractured along geopolitical lines, the latest u.s. tariffs highlight the growing challenges faced by middle-power economies caught between strategic competition and supply chain realignment. the asean+3 response signals a broader unease over unilateral protectionist measures and a desire to uphold stability through international cooperation and open markets.

why dont countries peg their currency to oil? in 2018 venezuela minted a crypto called the $petro but was too early imo. if kuwait or saudi minted a oil backed crypto pegged to a barrel of oil it will be used for oil trade. imo: should mint an oil backed token. : the only concrete example of a country attempting to back a currency with oil is venezuelaâ€™s $petro, launched in 2018. while the petro was claimed to be backed by venezuelaâ€™s oil reserves (one petro = one barrel of oil), its implementation was ineffective due to a lack of transparency, limited adoption, and eventual abandonment by 2024. no other country has successfully backed a currency with oil in the formal sense, though oil-rich nations often rely on oil revenues to support their currencies indirectly (e.g., saudi riyal, kuwaiti dinar). answer: yes, venezuela attempted to back a currency with oil through the petro, launched in february 2018. the petro was claimed to be backed by venezuelaâ€™s oil and mineral reserves, with each unit tied to the value of one barrel of oil. however, the initiative largely failed due to a lack of transparency, limited adoption, and its eventual abandonment by 2024. no other country has successfully backed a currency with oil, though oil revenues often support the economies of petrocurrency nations like saudi arabia and kuwait.

to meet u.s. treasury secretary janet yellen during his visit to switzerland. the ministry of commerce stated that china has agreed to engage in dialogues with the u.s. meanwhile, the ministry of foreign affairs emphasized the necessity for the u.s. to stop exerting pressure tactics. yellen expressed optimism over potential progress in trade negotiations in the coming weeks and remarked on the unsustainable nature of the 145% tariffs imposed on chinese goods during the trump administration. additionally, chinese a-share listed companies reported robust first-quarter results, with 75.46% achieving profitabilityâ€”showcasing the resilience of china's economy. on the domestic macroeconomic front, finance minister lan fo'an highlighted that china is committed to proactive macroeconomic policies to meet its 2025 growth target of approximately 5%. however, the caixin china services pmi in april fell to a seven-month low, signaling a slowdown in business expansion. data from the state taxation administration revealed accelerated investment in engineering projects in the first quarter, and the may day holiday saw domestic tourists' total spending, grow by 6.4% year-on-year, with 314 million domestic tourism tripsâ€”a 6.4% increase compared to the previous year. in financial policy updates, the state council's information office announced a forthcoming press conference to outline a comprehensive financial policy package aimed at stabilizing market expectations. vice governor of the pboc, xuan changneng, stated that the country is advancing legislation on deposit insurance law to strengthen its core deposit insurance functions. in domestic economic developments, first-quarter earnings of a-share listed companies reflected a strong start, with 75.46% of enterprises reporting profits, underscoring the country's economic momentum. this aligns with china's 2025 gdp growth target of around 5%, as reiterated by minister of finance liu kun, who also pledged to further open china's economy to the global market. a-share markets saw significant upward momentum on the first trading day after the may day holiday. the sse index rose 1.13%, closing at 3,395 points, while the shenzhen component index gained 1.84%, and the chinext index advanced 1.97%. the broader wind all china index surged by 1.62%. total market turnover expanded to 1.36 trillion yuan, with nearly 5,000 stocks seeing gains. chinese bond markets were also active, though the main treasury bond futures contracts saw mixed movements: the 10-year bond futures declined by 0.16%, while the 5-year bond futures slipped 0.09%. wind financialliteracy china marketupdate marketresearch newspicks news marketresearchreports

the evolution of saudi arabiaâ€™s trade with china, the eu, and the u.s. china has emerged as saudi arabiaâ€™s largest trading partner and the worldâ€™s leading importer of crude oil, while saudi arabia stands as chinaâ€™s primary trade partner in the middle east and its second-largest global crude oil supplier. in 2024, bilateral trade between the two countries reached $107 billionâ€”surpassing saudi arabiaâ€™s combined trade with the european union ($75 billion) and the united states ($26 billion). this shift underscores a broader realignment of saudi arabiaâ€™s economic ties toward asia, particularly in the context of chinaâ€™s growing influence in global energy markets. from 2000 to 2024, saudi-china trade expanded at a remarkable 15.9% compound annual growth rate (cagr), soaring from just $3.1 billion to $107 billion. over the same period, trade with the eu grew at a 4.5% cagr (from $26 billion to $75 billion), while trade with the u.s. increased at a modest 1.0% cagr (from $21 billion to $26 billion). these figures highlight chinaâ€™s rapidly rising share in saudi arabiaâ€™s global trade portfolio. saudiarabia usa eu china trade energy oil

6 years ago i was working at a gas station making $70 a day every day the same shit fill tanks, stock shelves, and wash windows for tips. now i trade fulltime and make more in a day than i used to in a month here are the 6 things that changed everything for me: 1-stop looking for the "holy grail" strategy 99% of strategies work if you can follow them 2- i wasted 2 years strategy hopping before i realized this trade one setup on one timeframe master it completely before you add anything else 3-be a risk manager first, trader second i blew 7 accounts thinking i was smarter than i was. soon as i started treating myself as the risk department, everything changed no trade happens without mapping out risk first. 4- trading is boring when done right if you're feeling an adrenaline rush, you're gambling not trading my most profitable days are when i take 2-3 trades max 5- keep a trading journal review it weekly and be brutally honest with yourself all my breakthroughs came from seeing my own patterns 6- you need to be uncomfortable comfort breeds laziness working 2 jobs, going to college, and trading was probably the best decision i could have made. most will read this, then do absolutely nothing different tomorrow the ones who actually implement will be the ones posting their success stories next year

nigeria customs service pledges support for renewable energy trade â€¦marks one year of advance ruling implementation the nigeria customs service (ncs) has reaffirmed its commitment to promoting seamless and sustainable trade operations, with a renewed focus on facilitating the importation of renewable energy technologies. the comptroller-general of customs (cgc), adewale adeniyi, who was represented by deputy comptroller-general of customs (dcg) caroline niagwan, in charge of the tariff and trade department, made the pledge in lagos on monday, 19 may 2025, during the 2025 edition of the ncs trade facilitation stakeholder consultative forum, which also commemorated one year anniversary of the advance ruling programme. held under the theme â€œtrade facilitation measures for renewable energy and energy efficiency technologies,â€ the forum brought together key industry stakeholders, development partners, and government officials to explore customsâ€™ evolving role in supporting nigeriaâ€™s transition to a low-carbon economy. delivering the keynote address, dcg caroline niagwan described trade facilitation as central to customsâ€™ contribution to national development and global sustainability efforts. â€œwith the increasing volume of global trade, it has become imperative for customs administrations to adopt mechanisms that support the seamless flow of legitimate trade. such mechanisms are essential not only for sustaining international commerce but also for enabling small and medium-sized enterprises (smes) to benefit from cross-border trade,â€ said dcg niagwan. she highlighted key initiatives introduced by the ncs to simplify and modernise customs operations, including the unified customs management system (ucms), codenamed bâ€™odogwu, the advance ruling system, and the authorised economic operator (aeo) programme. on nigeriaâ€™s environmental obligations, the dcg reiterated the ncsâ€™s support for the green customs initiative and multilateral environmental agreements such as the montreal protocol and the paris agreement. â€œthe nigeria customs service plays a pivotal role in supporting these national objectives by facilitating the importation of renewable energy technologies and implementing fiscal measures that promote a shift away from fossil fuels, with the ultimate goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2060,â€ she stated. as part of the advance ruling programme anniversary celebration, the dcg reaffirmed the serviceâ€™s commitment to fostering efficient, secure, and sustainable trade operations. a key highlight of the event was the official launch of the handbook on import and export procedures for renewable energy and energy-efficient technologies, which aims to provide guidance to stakeholders and traders on customs processes applicable to clean energy equipment. in a goodwill message, markus wagner, country director for nigeria and ecowas at giz, represented by duke benjamin, commended the ncs for its strategic foresight. he remarked that the initiative underscores the critical role of customs in advancing nigeriaâ€™s renewable energy aspirations. â€œtodayâ€™s launch represents another significant step towards improving the ease of doing business in nigeria,â€ he added. stakeholders present at the forum also shared testimonials on the positive impact of the advance ruling programme, applauding the ncs for its innovation and responsiveness to the trading community's needs.

an often overlooked edge is: identifying trade duration. the lionâ€™s share of my pnl has come from positions held over multiple weeks. i see too many people emulating a scalping style stemming largely from risk aversion rather than a desire to maximize ev. others hold positions so long they become â€œinvestorsâ€ rather than traders. ask yourself what trade duration has made you the most money, but also what trade duration you have the highest hit rate with. even amongst new pair memes, some narratives could take days or weeks to play out rather than an afternoon. you should question how long you expect a trade will take to play out before you even enter the position. far too often traders panic about intraday movements when their intention was to hold for a week +.

the strategy that brad is calling for (tesla to trade in it's own stock) is not only (extremely) risky from an investment perspective, it is (extremely) risky - foolhardingly so - from a legal perspective. to understand the legal jeopardy tesla would face, here is grok's very clear conclusion in it's analysis of the strategy: "conclusion: a nasdaq-listed company can legally repurchase its shares under strict conditions (rule 10b-18) and sell shares if compliant with registration and antifraud rules. however, actively trading its own stock to exploit dips and highs risks violating insider trading and market manipulation laws, especially if mnpi is involved or the activity misleads investors. legal counsel and adherence to sec regulations are critical to avoid liability." if you are interested in the detailed analysis, here is the full grok prompt and response. however, what grok does not analyze is the prospect of a full scale class action suit being brought by aggresive law firms on almost any/every trade conducted by the company (even those, and especially those, that make profits!) there is a reason that companies stick to buying their own shares strictly under the sec rule 10b-18 share buy back safe harbor, and almost never because they wish to "buy the dip". that form of trading almost automatically implies mnpi, even when none is involved! this is why directors and senior managers try to only buy or sell shares according to a published plan under safe harbor rules. this is a really bad idea: the only consolation is that it would never be approved by the legal counsel or the board of directors.

<my personal thoughts on natural gas> it's true that lng feed gas has been weak recently due to short-term maintenance, but that doesn't matter and won't last long. the key is the year-end lng ramp up. us lng exports, which have already been on the rise for several years, will once again significantly increase towards the end of the year. during this injection season, traders are bound to have an upside bias and will need to build much more stocks than normal. this is because everyone is anticipating the structural demand drivers, leaving the market extremely vulnerable to winter weather variability. we don't need 5-year avg stocks, we need more than that. nevertheless we are starting the beginning of the cooling demand season with a pretty good weather model. l48 production remains stagnant. as the us shale basins are being gasified, we are unlikely to see a dramatic decline in permian associated gas production despite lower oil prices, but we are certain to see slower growth than consensus at the start of the year. even in the traditional gas producing plays (appalachian, haynesville), we are seeing pretty good discipline. this is a huge opportunity for commodity funds or traders. you can buy producer stocks like $ar and $eqt to gain underlying exposure, and then continue to pursue additional gains through upside-biased short-term derivatives trading whenever the opportunity presents itself through the winter of 25/26. the only weakness of the natural gas bull thesis is that the bullish consensus is held by a majority of industry veterans, which is understandably uncomfortable when it seems so obvious. but so far, the natural gas market has worked very well. *i took advantage of the decline in early april to buy a lot of $ar common stock, and as i already mentioned, i'm doing some short-term buy trades on ng futures. natgas oott

chinaâ€™s coal calculus: security vs. sovereignt 1. geopolitical fuel triggers - taiwan and lng fears: china coal for several reasons: - 45% of its lng (liquefied natural gas) imports pass through the malacca strait, which is patrolled by the u.s. - coal is domestically abundant, with reserves totaling 137 billion tons. - nuclear limitations: nuclear power contributes only 5% of chinaâ€™s energy. it is too slow and expensive to significantly replace coal on a large scale before 2035. 2. the storage gap - china requires over 1,000 gwh of storage capacity for renewables to effectively replace coal, but currently, it has less than 50 gwh. - as a result, coal "peakers" are used to back up renewables during periods of low generation, which comes at a substantial costâ€”approximately 1.4 billion tons of coâ‚‚ emissions per year. 3. renewable contradiction - china is a leader in renewable energy, adding 230 gw in 2023: - however, the grid cannot integrate all this renewable energy without coal balancing, which saw an additional 48 gw of coal capacity added in 2023. - thus, coal is not replacing renewables; rather, it is facilitating their growth during a challenging transition. - for china, coal acts as a "transition" resource, providing vital energy sovereignty amid the looming threats of u.s. sanctions and the ongoing taiwan conflict.

more people unsubscribed from our free newsletter than any other day following wednesday's email. i sent out a newsletter outlining how we use relative strength to get into winning trades before everyone else. i used our trade on $cvx from late 2021 as a focal point: we bought the strongest sector, in stocks that were showing relative strength, in a market that was beginning to breakdown. it just so happened that russia invaded ukraine in february and our energy stocks shot up in value. we had no idea that was going to happen. and that was the point. someone else did. there was a reason why the market wasn't selling energy stocks. and we caught onto that and followed along and made a bunch of money. fast forward to last friday: the same situation. energy stocks were, out of no where, showing relative strength. crude oil was back up and over a key level that made us act and so we did. we bought $xom - and today they're up big. the news headlines get the praise, but the profits came from a position being opened last friday. 1 week ago. with no prior knowledge of war. it was relative strength; the second most important idea in our profits over prophets framework. i got replies back from wedneday night's email along the lines of: "how dare you make light of ukraines situation" or "this is sick. who cares about your profits?" i have bad news, folks. if you're in the market as a speculator, you have two choices: - act on what the market is telling you to make as much money as you possibly can, - get mad at everyone else who does it instead. i'd rather be the winner. it's that simple. relative strength matters. and it can make you a lot of money if you're willing to listen. anyway, we're long a few energy stocks. we'll see how this summer plays out.

i keep seeing people explaining to me that it doesn't matter if israel's strikes disrupt iranian oil exports since only china buys oil from iran. this is deeply confused, but that confusion seems very widespread, so it's worth explaining why. the oil market is global, so if you reduce iranian exports, it will increase prices for everyone and not just china because the chinese will have to get the oil they're no longer getting from iran from somewhere else and that will bid prices up. of course, that's not the only or even the main reason why the war increases oil prices, the main reason is that, because of the risk of regional spillover, as long as it lasts it creates uncertainty about the reliability of oil supplies and that's reflected in prices.

what are alternatives if iran closes the straits of harmouz, grok? if iran were to close the strait of hormuz, a critical chokepoint for roughly 20-30% of global oil trade, the primary alternative for oil and gas exports from the persian gulf would be limited-capacity pipelines bypassing the strait. hereâ€™s an overview of the main alternatives and their challenges: 1. existing pipelines saudi arabiaâ€™s petroline (east-west pipeline): capacity: approximately 5 million barrels per day (bpd). route: connects oil fields in eastern saudi arabia to the red sea port of yanbu, bypassing the strait of hormuz. status: has spare capacity of about 2 million bpd, but this is insufficient to cover the 17-20 million bpd typically transiting the strait. challenges: limited spare capacity, vulnerability to regional instability (e.g., houthi attacks in the red sea), and the need for upgrades to handle significantly increased volumes. abu dhabiâ€™s crude oil pipeline: capacity: around 1.5 million bpd. route: transports oil from abu dhabiâ€™s oil fields to the port of fujairah on the gulf of oman, bypassing the strait. status: can handle roughly 75% of the uaeâ€™s crude output, but this is a fraction of the regionâ€™s total exports. challenges: limited capacity and inability to compensate for other gulf producers like iraq or kuwait. iraqâ€™s pipelines: capacity: the iraq-turkey pipeline (partially operational) and southern export terminals like basra have limited bypass potential. challenges: many pipelines are outdated, under repair, or disrupted by geopolitical issues. iraq relies heavily on the strait for exports. iranâ€™s jask terminal: capacity: limited, designed to handle some of iranâ€™s own exports. route: located in the gulf of oman, bypassing the strait. status: operational since 2021 but primarily serves iranâ€™s needs, not other gulf producers. challenges: iranâ€™s own exports would be curtailed by a strait closure, and itâ€™s unlikely to share capacity with rivals. 2. unused or underutilized pipelines spare capacity: the u.s. energy information administration estimates about 2.6 million bpd of unused pipeline capacity from saudi arabia and the uae combined. challenges: this is far below the volume needed to replace strait exports. many pipelines are old, require maintenance, or face political and security risks (e.g., in yemen or syria). 3. non-pipeline alternatives overland transport: trucking oil or gas is impractical due to the massive volumes involved, high costs, and logistical complexities across conflict-prone regions. alternative sea routes: there are no viable maritime routes to bypass the strait of hormuz, as itâ€™s the only sea passage from the persian gulf to the open ocean. increased production elsewhere: countries like the u.s., russia, or canada could ramp up production, but this would take months and wouldnâ€™t fully offset the immediate loss of gulf oil. the u.s., now a major exporter, could mitigate some impact for western markets. strategic reserves: nations like the u.s., china, and members of the international energy agency could release strategic petroleum reserves to stabilize markets temporarily, but this is a short-term fix. 4. economic and geopolitical considerations impact on global markets: a closure would likely spike oil prices by 50% or more, potentially pushing prices above $100 per barrel, causing economic disruption worldwide. iranâ€™s own losses: closing the strait would cut iranâ€™s oil exports (1.65 million bpd in 2024), which account for 65% of its government revenue, risking domestic instability. military response: the u.s. fifth fleet, based in bahrain, and allied navies could reopen the strait through minesweeping, escorts, or airstrikes, though this risks escalation. china and india: as major importers of gulf oil, they would pressure iran to avoid closure, as it would harm their economies more than western nations. 5. practicality of closure iran has the capability to disrupt the strait using mines, anti-ship missiles, drones, or fast boats, but a sustained closure is unlikely due to international backlash and self-inflicted economic damage. historical precedent (e.g., the 1980s tanker war) shows iran has disrupted shipping but never fully closed the strait. conclusion the primary alternativesâ€”saudi and uae pipelinesâ€”offer limited capacity, covering only a fraction of the 17-20 million bpd transiting the strait. global oil markets would face severe disruption, with no immediate substitute for gulf exports. mitigation would rely on strategic reserves, increased non-gulf production, and military efforts to reopen the strait, but these are short-term or high-risk options. iranâ€™s own economic dependence on the strait makes a prolonged closure improbable. if youâ€™d like, i can dive deeper into specific pipeline logistics or model the economic impact of a closure. let me know!

on 10 june, zimbabwe announced that it would ban exports of lithium concentrates starting in 2027 to retain more profits from its rich mineral deposits through at least two firms with $1 billion in chinese investment willing to turn raw lithium into battery-grade lithium for electric vehicles and portable devices. this move follows a 2022 ban on exports of lithium ore (the raw mined material), part of a broader crusade to benefit zimbabweâ€™s economy and a trend amongst mineral-rich african states aiming to move beyond raw material exports. for example, namibia halted exports of unprocessed lithium and rare earths in 2023 to drive domestic processing. in 2021, the democratic republic of the congo tightened controls on cobalt and copper concentrates to encourage in-country refining. however, probably the most famous examples include those of the alliance of sahel states, comprising burkina faso, mali and niger. these three countries ousted western-aligned leaders in recent years and have embarked on a decolonisation process that includes reclaiming natural resources from foreign hands. returning to zimbabwe, the country boasts africa's largest lithium reserves and is among the world's top lithium producers. back in 2023, zimbabwean mines minister winston chitando said that zimbabwe needed to â€˜move up the value chain.â€™ the government had required producers to submit plans by march 2024 for local processing. quartz reports, â€˜battery makers anticipate that lithium-ion batteries will keep dominating the industry as they are now 30 times cheaper than when they first came to the market in the early 1990s.â€™

who has the most to lose if the strait of hormuz is shut down? not the us. itâ€™s china. china relies heavily on oil flowing through that chokepoint. nearly 45 percent of its total oil imports, about 5.4 million barrels per day, come through the strait of hormuz. a closure would cut off almost half of its crude supply and trigger a major energy crisis in china. not clear iran can actually pull it off.

us calls on china to prevent iran from closing strait of hormuz and disrupting global oil flows u.s. secretary of state marco rubio on sunday called for china to prevent iran from closing the strait of hormuz, one of the most important trade routes for crude oil in the world. "i encourage the chinese government in beijing to call them about that, because they heavily depend on the straits of hormuz for their oil," rubio said in an interview on fox news. china is iran's most important oil customer and maintains friendly relations with the islamic republic. iran's foreign minister warned earlier sunday that the islamic republic "reserves all options to defend its sovereignty," after the u.s. bombed three key nuclear sites over the weekend. iranian state-owned media, meanwhile, reported that iran's parliament backed closing the strait of hormuz, citing a senior lawmaker. however, the final decision to close the strait lies with iran's national security council, according to the report. an attempt to block the narrow waterway between iran and oman could have profound consequences for the global economy. some 20 million barrels per day of crude oil, or 20% of global consumption, flowed through the strait in 2024, according to the energy information administration. oil prices could shoot above $100 per barrel if the strait is closed for a prolonged period, according to goldman sachs and consulting firm rapidan energy. jpmorgan analysts view the risk of iran closing hormuz as low because the u.s. would view such a move as a declaration of war. rubio said it would be "economic suicide" for iran to close the strait because the islamic republic's oil also passes through the waterway. iran is the third-largest oil producer in opec, pumping 3.3 million barrels per day. it exports at least 1.6 million bpd, with nearly 80% sold to china, according to the eia.

closure of the strait of hormuz & the impact on the price of farm produce in nigeria. surge in oil and fuel prices: the strait of hormuz handles about 20% of global oil and 20% of lng trade. a closure could push brent crude oil prices to $120-$150 per barrel, or even $350 in extreme scenarios. nigeria, despite being an oil producer, relies heavily on imported refined petroleum products due to limited domestic refining capacity. a spike in global oil prices would increase the cost of petrol and diesel, potentially reaching n2,000-n3,000 per litre in nigeria. increased agricultural input costs: nigerian farmers depend on imported inputs like fertilizers, pesticides, and machinery fuel. the middle east, via the strait, supplies 16.3% of global seaborne fertilizer trade. a closure would disrupt these supplies, driving up prices. food inflation and supply chain disruptions: higher fuel and input costs would translate to elevated food prices. nigeriaâ€™s inflation rate, already high (around 32% in mid-2025), could worsen as transport and production costs due to our nigeriaâ€™s import-dependent economy. additionally, nigeria imports agricultural commodities like wheat and sugar through global trade routes affected by higher shipping costs and insurance premiums, exacerbating food price hikes. currency pressure and economic instability: nigeriaâ€™s reliance on oil exports (over 80% of foreign exchange earnings) means a global price spike could temporarily boost revenue, but a strait closure would disrupt trade logistics, weakening the naira due to higher import bills. a weaker naira would make imported inputs and food even more expensive, hitting consumers hard. rural farmers, often operating on thin margins, would struggle to absorb these costs, potentially reducing output and tightening food supply. mitigating factors: nigeria has strategic petroleum reserves covering 9-10 days of consumption, which could buffer short-term disruptions. diversified oil imports from russia, the u.s., and west africa (e.g., nigeriaâ€™s 5% crude imports from africa) could ease some pressure. however, these measures are insufficient for a prolonged closure, and global spare oil capacity (5.7 million bpd, mostly in saudi arabia and uae) is largely strait-dependent, limiting relief. estimated impact: based on historical precedents like the 1970s oil shocks, a sustained closure could double or triple transport and input costs, potentially increasing staple food prices (e.g., rice, yam, or tomatoes) by 30-50% within weeks. poorer households, spending 60-70% of income on food, would face severe hardship brace up dear farmers! we hope for dialogue sooner than later. summary: striat of hormuz closure will affect oil movement, which will affect food price in nigeria. smallholder farmers will be poorer, food prices will go up, and urban dwellers will spend more on food. farmersamson thewizardfarmer

another problem with the ca budget. they are now paying for fire suppression (about $1 billion) out of taxes that ca companies pay for climate change (also called cap & trade). we ultimately pay these taxes because they are passed on in higher gas prices, utilities and goods. it makes sense to pay for fire prevention out of this fund (removing brush, trees, dangerous fuels so that we donâ€™t have catastrophic fires with huge emissions). but they are only using $200 million to do that important work. paying for fire supression (firefighter response) makes no sense because that is responding to catastrophic fires that have already started, not preventing them. this has usually been a general fund cost but that is now being moved over to cap & trade to balance the budget. itâ€™s even more problematic because when they want to use that money for some new â€œgreenâ€ project like high speed rail, the firefighter budget will get cut. in sum this is very bad budget planning that leaves us short on wildfire prevention and vulnerable on funding our state firefighters.

iraq ranked first among the 12 opec producers in terms of exports to the united states. iraq has boosted exports in recent years, including to the united states, as it hasnâ€™t adhered to its supply quota under the opec+ agreements. but in may, iraq cut its crude oil production by 50,000 barrels per day (bpd) to 3.93 million bpd, compared to its target of 4.049 million bpd, according to thelatest opec datafrom secondary sources. iraq is compensating for previous overproduction as it has been one of the main overproducers in the opec+ deal for years, alongside kazakhstan and russia, non-opec members of the opec+ pact. iraq ranked first among the 12 opec producers in terms of exports to the united states in may. shipments totaled nearly 7 million barrels of crude, 6.95 million barrels to be precise. the second-largest opec supplier to the u.s. was nigeria with 6.803 million barrels of crude oil exports, followed by saudi arabia with 6.208 million barrels of crude. last month, estimates put iraqâ€™s crude oil exports to the united statessurging past 5 million barrelsin may, marking baghdadâ€™s highest monthly volume to u.s. refiners so far this year. the surge reflects sustained u.s. appetite for heavier middle eastern grades, with iraqi crude averaging between 160,000 bpd and 190,000 bpd in may. as opec+ maintains voluntary output curbs and u.s. shale growth moderates, iraq has solidified its position among washingtonâ€™s top five crude suppliers. iraqâ€™s export increase also provides critical fiscal relief for baghdad, with crude sales accounting for roughly 90% of iraqâ€™s state revenue. recent price support near $80 per barrel has further underpinned iraqâ€™s monthly revenues, helping finance public sector wages and infrastructure projects.

known as the "country of white gold," uzbekistan, located at the central asia, has rich resources of gold, cotton, petroleum, and natural gas. china and uzbekistan share a long history of trade dating back at least 2,000 years to the ancient silk road. with the development of the china-europe railway express, this vital economic lifeline has transported green beans, raisins, and other agricultural products to dining tables across china. launched in 2024, the china-kyrgyzstan-uzbekistan railway has further deepened connectivity across eurasia and is expected to be completed in the coming years. in recent years, uzbekistan has identified tourism as a key strategic industry, implementing a series of 'rapid reforms" aimed at the fundamental transformation of the entire sector. due to uzbekistan's visa-free policy to china since 2020, increasing numbers of chinese tourists are visiting the country, drawn to its more than 7,300 cultural heritage sites. in january, 2025, uzbekistan joined brics as a partner country. brics2025 mybricsstory bricsstory

fact: israel and iran maintained significant covert trade in oil and weapons until the late 1980s, with activity declining but not disappearing entirely into the 1990s. oil trade: â€¢from the mid-1950s until the 1979 iranian revolution, iran was israelâ€™s primary oil supplier, providing over 90% of israelâ€™s oil imports at times. this relationship was highly secretive, with both sides concealing the extent of their cooperation due to regional sensitivities and arab opposition. â€¢after the 1979 revolution, official diplomatic relations ceased, but clandestine oil trade continued into the 1980s. iranian oil was sold to israel through covert channels and intermediaries, such as the swiss trader marc rich, and transported via a secret pipeline. â€¢this covert oil trade persisted throughout the iranâ€“iraq war (1980â€“1988), with israeli arms sales to iran often being paid for in oil shipments. the arrangement reportedly continued sporadically and unofficially even after the war, though at a reduced scale. weapons trade: â€¢during the iranâ€“iraq war, israel was a major supplier of arms to iran, selling an estimated $500 million to $2 billion worth of weapons annually in the early 1980s. these included anti-tank guns, missiles, spare parts for aircraft, and other military equipment. â€¢much of this arms trade was facilitated with the tacit approval of the united states, particularly as part of efforts to prevent an iraqi victory and later as part of the iranâ€“contra affair (1985â€“1986). â€¢arms sales continued after the iranâ€“iraq war, but became more sporadic and unofficial, with some reports of israeli arms deals with iran into the early 1990s

the tropical main development region of the atlantic is currently warming significantly, and it can be easily seen as to why when looking 850mb wind charts over the last few days. weaker than average trade winds and vorticity within the intertropical convergence zone in the low-latitudes have allowed for reduced upwelling, and the sea surface temperature anomaly (ssta) configuration has improved as a result. with trade winds expected to continue being weaker than average over the next couple of weeks, favorable changes in the background state of the basin are possible with a weaker differential between tropical and subtropical sstas being present.

pull it off. hereâ€™s how: 1. the idea? crush russiaâ€™s oil exports, which fund ~40% of the kremlinâ€™s budget. but thereâ€™s a twist: he hates high oil prices more than any president in history. if markets are never perfect. instead, oil always finds a way. sellers and buyers meet â€” sanctions or not. but that is only true over time. in the short term, sanctions force all actors to reconsider their positions and thus absolutely create a supply shock to the market if introduced on a tight timeline. 3. today, india and china buy some 70% of russian crude, mostly at a discount. this isnâ€™t a loophole â€” itâ€™s by design. western sanctions aim to limit russiaâ€™s income while keeping prices manageable for the west. that is also why the west (us & europe) introduced the sanctions gradually over 12-15 months in 2022. it gave everyone the time to rearrange themselves. but trumpâ€™s approach may flip that script. he could introduce a tariff shock with immediate effect to which oil prices will react because â€” for the very least â€” the shorts are forced to cover their positions. 4. the proposed sanctioning russia act of 2025 targets countries helping fund russiaâ€™s war by continuing to import russian energy. it proposes a 500% tariff (!) on imports by the united states from countries (like india & china) that buy russian oil. 5. thatâ€™s a big stick. and trump could wield it effectively â€” if heâ€™s willing to stomach the oil price shock that might follow for a limited period. 6. the bill also includes an escape hatch, giving trump max leverage to negotiate peace with the kremlin: the president can issue a 180-day waiver to any country based on u.s. national security interests. a second waiver may be possible under certain conditions (per hill reporting). this gives flexibility â€” and leverage. â¸» bottom line: if trump backs this fully, it could mark the most aggressive energy sanctions in modern history. big oil, geopolitics, tariffs, and a high-stakes showdown with putin and oil markets â€” all in one. watch monday.

the european commission proposed on friday a floating price cap on russian oil of 15% below the average market price of crude in the previous three months, - reuters the cap bans trade in russian crude oil transported by tankers if the price paid was above $60 per barrel and prohibits shipping, insurance and re-insurance companies from handling cargoes of russian crude around the globe, unless it is sold for less than the price cap. the commission initially proposed in june to lower the cap from $60 a barrel to $45 a barrel as part of its 18th package of sanctions on russia.

on july 18, 2025, the eu agreed on the 18th sanctions package against russia, which provides for further restrictions on energy trade. the price of russian oil is now strictly limited to $47.6 per barrel â€“ approximately 15% below the average market price over the last three months. the sanctions package also includes a ban on transactions related to the nord stream 1 and 2 gas pipelines, meaning that russia's plans to "rescue" this infrastructure through the us are now futile. russia's hopes of blocking the adoption of the new package with the help of hungary and slovakia also did not materialize. slovakia received a guarantee of protection against gas supply disruptions until 2028 and supported the eu's joint decision. against this backdrop, india announced its readiness to replace russian oil with middle eastern oil. on july 17, indian minister of petroleum and natural gas hardeep singh puri confirmed that delhi was ready to switch from russia to other sources (brazil, canada, guyana, the middle east). the number of countries supplying oil to india has increased from 27 to 40 over the past month, confirming india's readiness to adapt quickly. how this will affect russia's economy: in the coming months, budget-generating oil and gas revenues should fall sharply (a reduction of at least 30â€“40% is forecast). inflation will accelerate, and the ruble will weaken; the room for circumventing sanctions is narrowing; if india switches to alternative suppliers, this will deprive russia of a market share that is extremely important to it; the introduction of sanctions on nord stream operations "shuts down" potential loopholes and moscow's "investment maneuvers" to return to the european market. the kremlin understands the severity of the economic consequences of continuing the war, but is not seeking a political solution. russia understands that the us is also considering the possibility of imposing new sanctions, but there are currently no signs that putin is ready for de-escalation and genuine peace talks. negotiations and the positions of the parties involved - the eu, the us, and china - are important factors that will determine how the situation develops and whether further sanctions will be imposed.

barzani/top us diplomat demand action on salary and oil pm barzani and amb. steven fagin agreed on the urgent need for salary payments from baghdad, the resumption of oil exports, and an end to drone attacks. they also called for a new krg government to be formed before iraqi elections. erbil (kurdistan24) â€“ prime minister masrour barzani and the top u.s. diplomat in iraq on saturday presented a united front on the kurdistan region's most critical challenges, agreeing on the urgent need for baghdad to release salary payments, for northern oil exports to resume, and for an end to drone attacks on energy infrastructure. in a high-level meeting in the kurdistan region on saturday, july 19, prime minister barzani hosted steven fagin, the chargÃ© d'affaires of the u.s. embassy in iraq. the meeting, also attended by u.s. consul general steve bitner, covered the general situation in iraq and the strengthening of bilateral relations. according to a readout of the meeting, both sides came to a clear consensus on several pressing issues. they agreed that the federal government "must send the kurdistan region's salaries and financial entitlements as soon as possible," and that the export of the region's oil through the turkish port of ceyhan "should resume in the near future." they also jointly stressed that the "terrorist and destructive drone attacks on the region's oil fields and energy infrastructure must stop." on the political front, both sides agreed that a new cabinet for the kurdistan regional government (krg) "must be formed before the iraqi parliamentary elections," adding a timeline to the long-delayed internal political process. during the discussion, ambassador fagin reaffirmed washington's support for the federal entity and for a "strong kurdistan region." in turn, the prime minister thanked the united states for its "continuous support." the points of agreement in the meeting touch on the core economic and security crises facing the kurdistan region. the salary dispute has been a long-standing source of friction with baghdad, leading to months-long delays in paying hundreds of thousands of public sector employees and causing significant economic hardship. the issue is tied to broader disagreements over budget allocations and revenue management. the call to resume oil exports addresses the halt in pipeline flows since march 2023, following an international arbitration court ruling in favor of baghdad. this shutdown has deprived the krg of its primary revenue source. furthermore, the demand for an end to drone attacks highlights a persistent security threat. the kurdistan region's energy infrastructure has been repeatedly targeted by drone and rocket strikes widely attributed to iran-backed militias, in what is seen as an effort to destabilize the region's energy sector.

china ditches u.s. lng as russian pipelines and domestic output surge: "over the past couple of years, china has become the worldâ€™s largest importer of liquefied natural gas (lng), surpassing japan as the top buyer of super-chilled gas since 2021. chinaâ€™s surging lng imports have been shaping asian energy flows, with the country accounting for more than 40% of the continent's total lng import growth. however, chinaâ€™s dominance in lng markets now appears in jeopardy, and we are seeing a prolonged decline in imports. according to ship-tracking data by kpler via bloomberg, chinaâ€™s lng imports are estimated to have clocked in at 5 million metric tons in june 2025, good for a hefty 12% year-on-year decline, marking the eighth straight month of declines. in the first four months of the year, chinaâ€™s lng imports slumped to 20 million tons, a sharp fall from 29 million tons from last yearâ€™s comparable period. full-year imports for the current year are now expected to fall 6â€“11% to 76.65 million metric tons. this trend appears to defy earlier projections for chinaâ€™s lng demand to continue growing through 2035. this, coupled with ongoing shifts in the countryâ€™s oil import dynamics, signals major changes in global energy flows. in 2023, china averaged 9.5 billion cubic feet per day in lng imports, with australia supplying 34% of total imports; qatar 23%, russia 11% and malaysia 10%. there are several factors driving this unexpected trend. first off, china has seen a significant increase in pipeline imports from russia and central asia, as well as a 6% increase in domestic gas production, both lowering lng demand. pipeline gas accounted for 41% of chinaâ€™s 16.0 bcf/d natural gas imports in 2023, with russia (via the power of siberia 1 pipeline), turkmenistan and myanmar supplying the majority. russia is actively increasing its pipeline gas exports to china as part of its strategy to reorient its energy exports away from europe and towards asia, with china as the leading target. specifically, the power of siberia 1 pipeline is expected to reach its full capacity of 38 billion cubic meters (bcm) by 2025, and a new pipeline, power of siberia 2, is planned to further increase exports to china by an additional 50 bcm per year. russia is also exploring other potential pipeline routes to china, including one that would transit through kazakhstan. this could further expand export capacity and provide alternative routes to diversify supply. second, trade tensions between washington and beijing have forced china to halt u.s. lng imports since march 2025 after trump slapped a punitive 125% tariff on its key trading partner. consequently, china redirected purchases to asian suppliers like qatar and indonesia. third, weak industrial demand due to slowing growth by chinaâ€™s industrial and chemical sectors has taken a toll on gas demand. these pivotal sectors are experiencing a slowdown due to a combination of factors including a broader economic slowdown, a struggling real estate market, weaker global demand for exports, and reduced foreign investments. to exacerbate matters, china's gdp growth is projected to slow down in the coming years despite showing resilience against u.s. tariffs, with forecasts suggesting growth below the official target and a further easing in 2026. the organisation for economic co-operation and development (oecd) has projected that chinaâ€™s economic growth will moderate from 5.0% in 2024 to 4.7% in 2025 and 4.3% in 2026. finally, a milder winter has lowered demand for residential heating particularly in northern china. chinaâ€™s falling lng imports are having ripple effects across global energy markets. weakening demand is freeing up lng volumes, easing supply pressure to other asian countries including japan and india as well as europe. falling chinese demand is also depressing asian spot lng prices, with prices dropping to $11/mmbtu in may 2025 from a february peak of $16.50/mmbtu. chinese buyers tend to turn to pipeline gas and domestic production whenever asian gas prices exceed $10/mmbtu. finally, the halt of u.s. lng exports to china threatens long-term contracts worth 20 million tons per year with u.s. suppliers. chinese lng buyers are now reselling u.s. cargoes to europe and also seeking new deals with asia-pacific and middle eastern suppliers, undermining u.s. export growth."

the u.s. blinks but champagne is on ice a no win situation of tariffs and sanctions that would cause widespread disaster to the us economy, especially oil, forced trump into a corner after russia's partners did not back down. having backed themselves into a tight spot, they became the first ones to blink with witkoff carrying the message. be in no doubt, trump asked for the meeting with putin and not the other way round. for the russians to be talking of a deal acceptable to them there must have been some very large concessions indeed by america. everyone around the world will be hoping this a genuine offer but always beware of greeks bearing gifts is a good yardstick here. not that america did not have some success in gaining what they wanted by tying russia up in a war at home they were able to overthrow assad in syria. on the ukraine front it had only one positive result which was the total capitulation and embarrassing surrender of europe and it's extremely weak leaders. in the space of three years most of the bigger countries in europe have had their economies ruined and many western leaders have fallen on the sword of supporting zelensky. marcron, merz and starmer along with von der leyen should be next. oh and don't forget that nobel peace prize so desperately wanted. the truth however is far different, with sanctions and tariffs against russia having the opposite effect and russia having unprecedented growth and on the battlefield it was an utter disaster. the problem being that as russia thrived and europe and america nose dived, weapons were unavailable to keep ukraine going much longer, catastrophic ukrainian losses were a major factor too. america will, of course, claim a glorious victory that fools nobody, it is a humiliating climb down wrapped in golden sunshine so bright one might require sunglasses. champagne all round, happy days are here again alright !? but the summit meeting with putin took three hours of convincing to get putin to agree to a summit meeting that was floated some time ago. the really wide awake among the world leaders will see right through this. trump's actual standing underneath the bluster and fanfare takes a large hit and putin's stock for the moment, has risen. the spin of the account of the meeting by america should set alarm bells ringing. the rhetoric of course will be that putin folded and russia made a mistake not getting the truth out but the russians don't really care for spin. there is nothing signed and sealed and russia have conceded nothing so far. an improvement in relations is not linked to a solve in ukraine, even though america will spin it as such. putin is in no hurry, it is america and europe in a rush and zelensky is so desperate he will fly to wherever they meet if abroad, in the vain hope of being invited to sit with the big boys. as for european leaders they will be briefing zelensky like men possessed trying to look relevant on the world stage, when they are nothing but gallery watchers. europe and the neocons will be beside themselves with fury that trump may have woken up to his perilous position at the eleventh hour. one should remember that kissinger once said that being an enemy of america was dangerous but being a friend of america is absolutely lethal. something the nobodies of europe and the comedian of ukraine have still to learn. the men of ukraine have learned this at a terrible cost. warren thornton investigative journalist

our canadian canola industry is every bit as important to our economy and jobs as canadian steel, aluminum, auto manufacturing and forestry. and a lot more significant than the electric vehicle industry. here is my statement on the 76 per cent tariffs on canola imposed by china today.

beijingâ€™s newly announced tariffs of over 75 percent on canadian canola seed are yet another unjustified attack on our farmers. this new and disastrous tariff is on top of the 100 percent tariffs previously imposed in march on canadian canola meal and oil, peas, and 25 percent tariffs on pork and seafood products, effectively locking our producers out of their market. china is the second largest customer for canadian canola, behind only the united states. these punitive new measures will devastate canadaâ€™s canola exports to china, which totalled $5 billion last year, and damage our agri-food trading relationship. prime minister carney is losing and canada is paying the price. he has failed to get beijingâ€™s tariffs lifted; failed to support our farmers and seafood producers. and now, the tariffs are getting worse. mark carney told us he was a master negotiator who could diversify our markets. yet he is losing trade wars all around the world, as canadian farmers, seafood producers, auto, steel, aluminum and other workers are paying a terrible price. we stand ready to work with the government to fight and remove these tariffs and restore markets for our farmers and businesses. the time for action is now.

as the canola industry does what it can to navigate the federally imposed hardships, we echo their call and the call of every single western canadian farmer, for ottawa to act! trash the ev tariffs and signal our desire for free and open trade.

institutions likely accumulated $tsla in q2 2025. $tsla outperforming during the april tariff crash while continuing to follow wyckoff accumulation strongly suggests institutions were buying. 13f filings are due on 8/14/25. this will show us institutional buys and sells during q2 2025. the most recent data shows us institutions own 1.816b shares of $tsla or 56.33% of the company. this period covered april, may, and june, which was a volatile period for $tsla. i want to cover this because $tsla was in a critical part of wyckoff accumulation called phase b, where we typically see large shake outs known as the spring, where volume spikes on a large move lower. this typically lines up with capitulation and major bottoms. after the spring, $tsla consistently made higher lows with every pullback, and most importantly, with declining volume. this is signals selling pressure is slowly exhausting. cvd during q2 2025 was positive, which suggests institutions were buying. letâ€™s see who bought and sold during the quarter and what the total institutional holdings look like.
