farms or ev's . priorities people. this from jake leguee when policy becomes a farmerâ€™s biggest threat by jakeposted onaugust 13, 2025 chinaâ€™s canola tariffs show how ottawaâ€™s choices can cripple canadian agriculture. farmers can handle a lot, from droughts to floods, rising input costs, and volatile markets. we manage risk for a living. but thereâ€™s one threat we canâ€™t outwork, outsmart, or insure against: our own governmentâ€™s policies. it doesnâ€™t have to be this wayâ€”government policy could be-should be-one of our greatest assets. farmers used to worry far more about other matters in the past: weather, markets, input prices, even labour. obviously, these are all critical drivers of our income year to year, and how we manage these determines our long-term success in this business. risks we can control that last point is keyâ€”those are manageable pieces of our business. i can manage labour challenges. i can manage input and capital costs to keep my costs low. careful, strategic management of these factors can make a tremendous difference to farm profitability over time. i can also buy insurance to protect me against a bad year, or maybe two (some farmers in long-term droughts would rightfully insist that insurance only goes so far). some insurance can even protect revenue itself, which also helps with commodity price collapses. i can also pre-sell crops, sometimes with production contracts that give me an out for bad weather, and some on futures markets that donâ€™t commit me to physical sales. there is a lot i can at least partially control. the more i manage my risk, the better my farm is likely to perform across decades. government policy, though, is not controllable. it is not predictable. increasingly, it is not rational. and it is incredibly impactful. chinese tariffs: a critical blow on august 12, 2025, china announced they would be imposing a 75.8 percent duty on canadian canola seed imports, effective august 14th. this isnâ€™t their first attack on canadian canola: on march 20, 2025, china also slapped a 100 percent tariff on canadian canola oil and meal. these two actions essentially close the door on this market. whatâ€™s the impact? in 2024, we exported $4.9 billion worth of canola, including seed, oil, and meal, to china. this is a critically important market. and letâ€™s not forget the serious impact on peas, pork, and other products china has targeted. it isnâ€™t just canola. the real reason behind chinaâ€™s move why is china doing this? oh, thereâ€™s some claimed â€œdumpingâ€ of canola into chinese markets and subsidies to canadian farmers from our government. but that is simply an excuse. canadian farmers are subsidized far less than many other countries, including most european countries and the united states. the real reason is because canada imposed a 100 percent tariff on chinese electric vehicles in october of 2024. this was supposedly done to protect canadaâ€™s auto industry. china is striking back to pressure the canadian government. ottawaâ€™s choices matter the federal government made a choice last october and continues to make the same choice today: sacrifice western canada for eastern canada. the auto industry is a key source of votes in the east. the west is not. the canola industry is worth $43 to $45 billion, employing 200,000 people. it alone, without considering any of the other crops we grow out west, is significantly larger than steel, aluminum, and auto manufacturing combined. this doesnâ€™t need to be a competition, though. every industry in canada is essential to its short and long-term prosperity. all weâ€™re asking is to be treated equally â€”to be offered the same level of support and attention the auto industry gets when trade barriers arise. doesnâ€™t the canadian government already support farmers? our federal and provincial governments cost share part of the cost of our crop insurance system. they also provide a revenue stabilization insurance product called agristability, which recently got a couple of needed improvements. obviously, crop insurance doesnâ€™t protect farmers against commodity price collapse, as that is a yield protection product only. agristability does â€“ but its support levels are so far below profitability that farmers are losing a lot of money before it kicks in. and that is a common misconception: agristability cannot help us in this situation, not really. what the loss of the chinese market does is remove our profit margin. agistability will not kick in to protect a profit, only reducing losses. this product cannot help us here. farmers are bearing the burden of government policy protecting one industry to spite anotherâ€“one thatâ€™s orders of magnitude larger. we have spent the money on this crop. our investment is in. the fertilizer, herbicides, fungicides, and insecticides are applied. the fuel is burned, the machinery used. and now, on the brink of harvest, we just lost our profit margin on one of our most important crops. china knows exactly what itâ€™s doing. they knew how to hit us where and when it hurts the most. but are they overestimating how interested our federal government is in doing something about it? this is far bigger than farmers this action by china isnâ€™t just an attack on farmersâ€”itâ€™s an attack on all of canada. this affects everyone, all across this country. the policies our governments, federally and provincially, put in place have an enormous impact on our livelihoods. from investment in crop breeding and infrastructure, to developing and maintaining trade agreements and market access, to providing insurance backstops, government policy matters. something must change itâ€™s time for our government to stop biting the hand that feeds it. itâ€™s time to recognize the enormity of the canadian agriculture. the success of farmers across this country drives the prosperity of millions of canadians. yet, time and again, the government enacts policies that actively damage agriculture. from ill-conceived climate policy, to falling investment in critical agriculture canada breeding programs, to repeated diplomatic blunders that alienate key export markets. something must change. agriculture is one of canadaâ€™s largest industries, providing 8 percent of gdp and one in eight jobs. it could be one of canadaâ€™s crown jewelsâ€”a target for strategic investment and clear, consistent policy to ensure success for generations. government policy can, should, must be an asset to canadian farmers, not a burden. something must change. canadians, if there ever was a time to talk to your mpâ€™s and tell them why agriculture matters, itâ€™s now. share this: x facebook linkedin reddit email like this: related investment in agriculture: boosting canadaâ€™s future december 7, 2024 in "advocacy" donâ€™t tell farmers how to farm â€“ ask them instead april 16, 2022 in "a farmer's views" the war on agriculture is not over yet february 24, 2025 in "advocacy" posted in a farmer's views, advocacy published by jake i am a farmer from near weyburn, saskatchewan, canada. we grow durum, wheat, canola, peas, lentils, and flax. i farm with my family, including my wife and three young sons, along with several other family members. we are a 3rd-generation farm that strives to continually improve - to leave things better than we found them. i'm involved in various places in the agriculture industry as well to try and build a better future. as a farmer and an agronomist, agriculture, and the science and business therein, is my fascination and my passion.

pushing defi to the next level: why better ux is the key, with goat network leading the charge defi has changed how people borrow, lend, trade, and earn yield without intermediaries. yet adoption is still slow. most users find defi difficult to navigate. wallet setups, gas fees, cross-chain bridges, and technical jargon create barriers that push many away. the most effective way to grow defi is through better user experience. incentives may bring temporary attention, and regulation takes time. ux, on the other hand, delivers immediate impact by making defi safer, easier, and more approachable. why ux matters makes onboarding simple for newcomers. reduces costly errors and security risks. builds trust and long-term retention. expands participation beyond crypto-native users. creates a cycle of growth, with more users leading to more liquidity and stronger ecosystems. i will be using as an example launched in 2024 as a bitcoin layer 2, goat network focuses on sustainable btc yield. users can stake btc or doge and earn yield directly from sequencer fees. the design is intentionally simple, avoiding complex mechanics that overwhelm beginners. during its pre mining campaign, the project attracted $8 million worth of btc and doge, showing early trust. its btc yield dashboard highlights clear products: goat safebox with 2% apy for low-risk users. btcb/dogeb vault with 10% apy for more active defi participants. the platform avoids synthetic assets and custodial bridges, keeping transparency at the core. onboarding is gamified through the â€œone piece project,â€ offering guides, nfts, and point-based rewards. the ecosystem extends with goatswap, oku, and artemis finance, giving users tools for swapping, staking, and farming. why users love goat network 1) smooth bridging between bitcoin l1 and goat l2 has been achieved. a new improvement was made today. 2) trust minimized bridge using bitvm2. 3) decentralized sequencer staking that feels open and fair. 4) clear yield options with visible risk levels. 5) gamified participation that encourages ongoing engagement. 6) balanced appeal for both serious btc holders and meme driven traders. the lesson to be learnt here better ux is the most direct driver of defi adoption. goat network shows how simple onboarding, transparent products, and engaging participation make a difference. incentives and regulation still play roles, but ux solves the accessibility problem today. for defi to scale, platforms must focus on making participation effortless without losing sight of security and transparency. defispiceathon spicenetisfordefi

europe was powerful only as long as it could benefit from africa's resources. without africa's oil, gas, minerals, rare earths, and agricultural exports, we are lost. for centuries, europeâ€™s strength has rested not only on its own productivity, but on what it could extract, control, or purchase cheaply from africa. the colonial empires of britain, france, and others turned african resources into the lifeblood of european industry. later, even after decolonization, europe continued to draw on african oil, gas, uranium, cobalt, and food exports to sustain its prosperity. this external supply chain allowed europe to mask its own demographic decline, its lack of raw materials, and its increasing dependency. today the illusion of independence is fading. europe does not have the energy reserves to power itself, nor the rare earths to sustain a modern digital economy. its agriculture relies on imported fertilizers and food flows connected to africa. the continent that once dictated terms now finds itself vulnerable. if africa withholds or redirects its resources â€” toward china, russia, or its own internal development â€” europe faces shortages, inflation, and industrial decline. the uncomfortable truth is that europe is not self-sufficient and never has been. its power has always depended on africa being weak, divided, and open to exploitation. now that africa asserts itself and diversifies its partners, europe is left exposed. climate change may one day alter the planet, but europeâ€™s collapse may come sooner â€” when the flow of oil, gas, minerals, rare earths, and agricultural exports from africa slows, and the continent realizes how little it can do on its own.

enterprises operating in the zone to promote trade facilitation and enhance revenue generation. customs area controller, comptroller immaculata nyong, disclosed this after a three-week tour of facilities and enterprises in the zone. the exercise, which ran from 29 july to 19 august 2025, covered companies including seplat energy, esso exploration and production nigeria (fze), totalenergies, onne multipurpose terminal (omt), west african container terminal (wact), technip fmc nigeria ltd, baker hughes, one subsea offshore systems ltd, intels nigeria ltd, oil tools africa ltd, titan tubular nigeria (fze), hamilton technologies nigeria ltd, and brawal oil service ltd (fze). comptroller nyong, accompanied by senior command officers and officials of the oil and gas free zone authority, engaged with operators, received operational briefings, and inspected ongoing activities. she explained that the tour was designed to strengthen stakeholder collaboration, ensure regulatory compliance, facilitate legitimate trade, and boost federal government revenue. â€œtrade facilitation cannot be achieved in isolation. our goal is to build synergy with enterprises in the oil and gas free zone, address concerns, and sustain an enabling environment for businesses to thrive,â€ she said. while many operators commended the ncs for its openness and active engagement, some raised concerns about operational challenges, particularly regarding the bâ€™odogwu clearance system. in response, comptroller nyong reassured stakeholders of the serviceâ€™s commitment to resolving such issues and improving efficiency in line with the comptroller-general of customsâ€™ mandate. she further emphasised that the command would maintain regular engagements with operators to ensure smooth operations and strengthen nigeriaâ€™s competitiveness as an oil and gas logistics hub.

chinaâ€™s tariffs on canadian peas in march 2025, china imposed retaliatory tariffs of 100% on imports of canadian peas (along with canola oil and meal), effective march 20, 2025. this was in response to broader trade tensions, including canadaâ€™s tariffs on chinese electric vehicles and other goods, amid escalating u.s.-initiated trade wars under the trump administration. the tariffs have severely disrupted canadian pea exports to china, a major market for pulses. prior to the tariffs, canada exported hundreds of thousands of tonnes of yellow peas to china annually (e.g., about 500,000 tonnes in 2024, valued at over cad 300 million). the duties have rendered these exports uncompetitive, causing a sharp drop in demand, oversupply in other markets, and downward pressure on prices. as of august 2025, the tariffs remain in place, with industry groups like pulse canada and alberta pulse growers highlighting the â€œdevastatingâ€ impact on the sector. the canadian government has provided support for affected farmers, but resolution remains uncertain amid ongoing global trade frictions. current pea prices in western canada (as of august 25, 2025) the tariffs have exacerbated a bearish market for yellow peas in western canada (primarily saskatchewan and alberta, which account for over 90% of production), leading to significantly lower prices due to lost chinese access, increased domestic production (seeded area up ~9.5% to 1.42 million hectares for 2025-26), and softening global pulse demand from northern hemisphere harvests. this has resulted in oversupply and muted export opportunities to alternatives like india or europe. prices vary by variety, region, and delivery terms (e.g., farmgate vs. delivered to elevator), with yellow/feed peas bearing the brunt of the decline. recent reports confirm farmgate and spot bids in western canada have fallen to as low as cad 6.00 per bushel for yellow peas, reflecting the userâ€™s observation of â€œbut ow $6.00 a bushelâ€ (interpreting this as â€œbut now $6.00 a bushelâ€ amid the tariff-induced slump). this is a notable drop from earlier 2025 levels (e.g., new crop bids were $1.50â€“2.00 higher in july) and the 2023-24 crop year average of ~cad 11.54â€“12.45 per bushel for 1can grade field peas. while some delivered bids remain higher, farmgate prices in saskatchewan and northern alberta are indeed at or below cad 6.00/bu in spot markets, signaling distress for producers. hereâ€™s an updated summary based on mid-to-late august 2025 data:

u.s. tariffs of 50 percent took effect wednesday, aug. 27, on many indian products, doubling an existing duty as u.s. president donald trump sought to punish new delhi for buying russian oil. trump has stepped up pressure on india over the energy transactions, a key source of revenue for moscow, as part of a campaign to end the ukraine conflict. while trump has slapped fresh duties on allies and competitors alike since returning to the presidency in january, this 50-percent level is among the highest that u.s. trading partners face. however, exemptions remain for sectors that could be hit with separate levies, including pharmaceuticals and computer chips. the trump administration has launched investigations into these and other sectors that could culminate in further duties. smartphones are in the list of exempted products as well. industries that have already been singled out, such as steel, aluminum and automobiles, are similarly spared these countrywide levies. the united states was india's top export destination in 2024, with shipments worth $87.3 billion. but analysts have cautioned that a 50 percent duty is akin to a trade embargo and is likely to harm smaller firms. new delhi has criticized washington's move as "unfair, unjustified and unreasonable." the world's fifth-largest economy is looking to cushion the blow, with indian prime minister narendra modi promising to lower the tax burden on citizens during an annual speech to mark india's independence. modi earlier vowed self-reliance as well, pledging to defend his country's interests. russia accounted for nearly 36 percent of india's total crude oil imports in 2024. buying russian oil saved india billions of dollars on import costs, keeping domestic fuel prices relatively stable. indian oil, the country's biggest and state-owned refiner, has said it will continue to buy russian crude depending on the economics, company sources told reuters last week.

exposing tarrifs hypocrisy: facts vs. claim the attack on india over russian oil is a textbook case of double standards. while the trump administration imposes punitive 50% tariffs on indian goods and brands india a â€œmoney laundromatâ€ for russia, the united states itself quietly sustains and even expands, its trade with moscow. americaâ€™s own dependency on russian commodities tells the real story: despite a 2024 law banning russian uranium, washington imported $596 million worth in the first five months of 2025 alone, a 28 percent year-on-year jump, under waivers that remain valid until 2028. fertilizer imports touched $806 million, up 21 percent, while palladium imports rose 37 percent to $502 million. all of these are exempted because they are considered â€œstrategic necessitiesâ€ for american industry and food security. the overall trade picture is just as striking. in 2024, us-russia bilateral trade amounted to $3.5 billion, with the us running a $2.4 billion trade deficit with moscow. between january and may 2025, american imports from russia rose another 23 percent, reaching $2.1 billion. meanwhile, europeâ€™s exposure to russian energy dwarfs both the us and india. the eu imported $41 billion worth of russian goods in 2024, including record lng purchases of $8.5 billion. france alone accounted for 37 percent of europeâ€™s russian lng intake. by contrast, indiaâ€™s record reveals a steady diversification. the russian share of indian arms imports has fallen to 36 percent from 55 percent a decade ago, with france and the us steadily rising as suppliers. india also exported $84.2 billion worth of refined petroleum in 2024, much of it to europe, countries fully aware that these products were refined from russian crude. the hypocrisy is clear. the us defends its own russian uranium and fertilizer imports as unavoidable because there are â€œno alternatives,â€ yet it penalizes india for purchasing crude vital to its energy security. mr. navarroâ€™s charge that india acts as an â€œoil money laundromatâ€ ignores the fact that western economies remain far more dependent on russian commodities than india ever was. what emerges is not a matter of principle, but of selective trade politics; shielding own interests while punishing others.

request for comments on the draft net billing regulations 1. nigeria's solar energy capacity has experienced significant growth in recent years. in 2023, solar panel imports were valued at over $200 million, translating to more than four million panels, with a substantial portion allocated to captive power generation. by q1 2025, the value of imported solar panels had reached approximately â‚¦125.29 billion. this expansion reflects the increasing adoption of renewable energy, particularly in rural and off-grid areas, driven by government initiatives and private sector investments. in 2024, nigeria added 63.5 mw of solar capacity, bringing the total installed capacity to 385.7 mw, further accelerating the shift towards decentralized energy solutions. 2. given this expansion, stakeholders have approached the commission with requests to explore the possibility of implementing a net metering arrangement, enabling the export of excess power back into the grid for commercial value. in compliance with its business rules and pursuant to sections 46 and 48 of the electricity act (ea) 2023, which govern the commissionâ€™s proceedings, consultations, and public hearings, the commission has developed draft regulations on net billing. 3. the commission is inviting the general public to provide comments on the draft net billing regulations which can be accessed at all comments, submissions, and further inquiries should be directed to: netbillingregulations.gov.ng. submissions can be made until 26 september 2025. 4. while anticipating constructive contributions to the draft regulations, please accept the assurances of the commission's best wishes. signed management nigerian electricity regulatory commission nerc netbilling renewableenergy nigeria regulation

signed a final draft agreement regarding the resumption of the kurdistan regionâ€™s oil exports. erbil, kurdistan region of iraq â€“ negotiating delegations from erbil and baghdad on thursday met in the iraqi capital to iron out the final details of an agreement on the outstanding issues between the two governments, relating particularly to the issues of the handover of the kurdistan region's domestic revenues to the federal government and of the resumption of the regionâ€™s oil exports. the meeting yielded no solutions to the issues between the two governments regarding the kurdistan region's handover of domestic non-oil revenues and resuming oil exports, the new region has learned. the new region understands that the federal government insists that the kurdistan regional government (krg) hand over 100 percent of the domestic revenue generated in the region. erbil and baghdad are in agreement over the protocol for resuming oil exports, however, the international oil companies (ioc) operating in the region require guarantees that they will be compensated 16 us dollars for each barrel of oil produced, a requirement that baghdad has refused to guarantee as of the time of writing this article. the kurdish delegationâ€™s visit was preceded by another delegation that left for baghdad on tuesday to discuss solutions with representatives from the federal government toward the same issues, focusing mainly on the resumption of oil exports. iraqi finance minister taif sami, in a letter addressed to the krg in late may, claimed that erbil had already exhausted its share of the 2025 federal budget, saying that the finance ministry will no longer fund the regionâ€™s civil servant salaries; war according to the former director general of the un office in vienna and executive director of the un office on drugs and crime (merged into the un office on drugs and crime), with the rank of under-secretary-general, the world's leading expert on drugs, pino arlacchi: "this is another attempt by the us to interfere in a country that - according to the un - has eradicated cocaine, marijuana colombia, bolivia, peru and brazil, but i have never visited venezuela. there was simply no need. the cooperation of the venezuelan governmentâ€™s record on combating the drug trade was among the best in latin america. the country was full of problems, but it was not involved in the production, trafficking, or even consumption of hard drugs. these are verified facts that today, in trumpâ€™s delusional narrative of â€œvenezuela as a narco-state,â€ clearly show that these are geopolitically motivated slanders. the analyses from the world drug report 2025, published by the organization i had the honor of leading, tell the exact opposite story to that propagated by the trump administration. they shatter the fiction of the cartel de los solesâ€”an alleged supercartel as legendary as the loch ness monster, but suitable for justifying sanctions, embargoes, and threats of military intervention against a country thatâ€”coincidentallyâ€”sits on some of the largest oil reserves on the planet. the recently released un report on 2025 is crystal clear and should shame those who have been behind the demonization of venezuela. the document mentions venezuela only in passing, stating that only a negligible part of colombian drug production passes through its territory to the us and europe. according to the un, venezuela has consolidated its historical position as a country without growing coca, marijuana, etc. â€“ and without the presence of international criminal cartels. the document only confirms 30 previous annual reports that do not mention the venezuelan drug trade at all, because it simply does not exist. only 5% of colombian drugs transit through venezuela. a full 2,370 tons â€“ ten times more â€“ are produced or traded by colombia itself, and 1,400 tons pass through guatemala. the â€œcartel de los solesâ€ is a figment of trumpâ€™s imagination. it is not mentioned in un documents, nor in european or other international agencies. only the dea in the us refers to it â€“ and that on the basis of classified data that would certainly not be secret if they had a real basis and confirmation from elsewhere. according to a european report, cocaine is the second most used drug in the eu. its main sources are clearly defined: colombia (production), central america (distribution) and various routes through west africa (transportation to europe). this bloomberg snapshot gives a live view of u.s. natural gas flows across production, demand, imports/exports, and lng movements. key takeaways: production: u.s. gas production is still very strong â€” hovering at record levels despite minor daily declines. demand: power burn remains the dominant demand driver, especially with summer cooling load â€” but it will ease as shoulder season begins. imports/exports: lng exports remain a critical balancing factor â€” sabine (+0.8 bcf), cameron (+0.1 bcf), freeport (+0.06 bcf) all pulling volumes offshore. u.s. gas flows show a market still flush with supply (~107 bcf/d), but lng exports (+14.6 bcf/d) and strong power burn (~38 bcf/d) are keeping balances tighter. canada imports sliding, mexico exports firm, and lng terminals remain the swing factor in whether we stay oversupplied or not. natgas

kurdistan region oil exports to resume soon- somo chief â€œi am optimistic about the positive measures and discussions taking place. everyone is working in this direction, and this is cause for optimism. all that remains is implementation so we are optimistic that it will be achieved soon.â€ ali nasir faiq, director general of soma erbil, kurdistan region - the head of iraqâ€™s state oil marketing organization (somo) said on monday that they are â€œworking to implement the agreed-upon termsâ€ to resume the kurdistan regionâ€™s long-halted oil exports, with exports expected to restart â€œsoon.â€ oil companies operating in the kurdistan region are demanding a tripartite signed agreement that includes the federal oil ministry and the kurdistan region's natural resources ministry to guarantee the payment of their dues. faiq stressed that somo is ready and â€œworking to implement the agreed-upon termsâ€ to resume the oil exports, stressing that the budget law and its amendments are the â€œstrongestâ€ guarantee for the payment of the companiesâ€™ dues. oil exports from the kurdistan region through the iraq-turkey pipeline have been suspended since march 2023, when a paris-based arbitration court ruled in favor of baghdad against ankara, saying the latter had violated a 1973 pipeline agreement by allowing erbil to begin exporting oil independently in 2014. the suspension has incurred $28 billion in lost revenue so far, according to the kurdistan regional government (krg). the following is the full transcript of the interview with ali nizar faiq: rudaw: there was much talk about reaching an agreement between baghdad and erbil, but this was followed by reports indicating that no agreement had been reached. where do we stand now regarding the export of the kurdistan region's oil through somo? ali nizar faiq: the question is important, and the issue is even more important. we are directly linked to the issue through the budget law and its amendments. the law stipulates the need to begin pumping the kurdistan region's oil in two directions: the first is exporting oil through the oil marketing company that we manage, and the other is domestic consumption. discussions began based on this foundation to establish the appropriate mechanism for implementing this law and its amendments, including selecting an international consultant and determining its work methodology. furthermore, the ministry of oil appointed wood mackenzie as a global consultant. discussions were also held with the kurdistan region's ministry of natural resources, which is responsible for its contracts with producing companies within the region and the rights and obligations of these companies under the contracts signed with them. these discussions resulted in somo completing all its contracts with the companies purchasing kurdistan region oil. we are optimistic that these quantities will arrive and flow into the tanks at the turkish port of ceyhan, after which loading will begin normally. so, based on the agreement, is the buyer currently ready? yes. the companies purchasing kurdistan region oil are ready. it is iraqi oil, flowing through iraqi-turkish pipelines in accordance with the existing agreement with the turkish side.

european countries as sponsors of war. in august 2025, the five largest eu importers of russian fossil fuels paid russia a combined eur 979 mn for fossil fuels. natural gas â€” unsanctioned by the eu â€” accounted for more than 61% of these imports, delivered mainly by pipeline or as liquefied natural gas (lng). the remainder was largely crude oil, which continues to flow to hungary and slovakia through the southern branch of the druzhba pipeline under an eu exemption. hungary was the euâ€™s largest importer, purchasing eur 416 mn worth of russian fossil fuels. this included eur 176 mn of crude oil and eur 240 mn of pipeline gas. slovakia ranked second, with imports totaling eur 276 mn. crude oil delivered via the druzhba pipeline made up 74% of the total (eur 204 mn), while pipeline gas accounted for eur 72 mn. the derogation allowing slovak refineries to process russian crude into oil products and re-export them to czechia expired on 5 june. france was the third-largest buyer, importing eur 157 mn of russian fossil fuels, all in the form of lng. however, not all of this gas is consumed domestically â€” a study shows that some lng entering through the dunkerque terminal is subsequently delivered to germany. the netherlands was the fourth biggest importer, importing eur 65 mn of russian lng, while belgium, in fifth place, purchased eur 64 mn, also entirely in lng.

china threatened to respond to nato countries imposing tariffs due to russian oil purchases. trade-economic and energy cooperation between china and countries around the world, including russia, is legal, said foreign ministry representative lin jian. china will take decisive countermeasures if nato countries, under pressure from the us, attempt to impose tariffs on the people's republic under the pretext of purchasing russian oil. this was stated by the official representative of the chinese foreign ministry, lin jian. "normal trade-economic and energy cooperation between china and countries worldwide, including russia, is legal and raises no objections," he emphasized at a briefing, commenting on the possibility of g7 and nato countries imposing tariffs on china for importing russian oil. "in case of violation of china's legitimate rights and interests, it will decisively take countermeasures; we will firmly defend our sovereignty, security, and development interests." as the chinese diplomat clarified, the actions of the united states, trying to pressure the european union, are "a typical example of unilateral intimidation and economic coercion." he noted that washington thereby "seriously undermines international trade rules, threatens the security and stability of global production and supply chains." "facts have proven that coercion and pressure are unpopular and do not solve problems," added lin jian. two majors

iraqi dinar revaluation: the resumption of oil today has been historical for iraq here is why the resumption of kurdistan crude oil exports through somo, as announced on september 16, 2025, cannot proceed to full international market integration without an iraqi dinar revaluation and forex listing this year, as global buyers demand transactions in freely convertible currencies to mitigate exchange rate volatility. this agreement, committing the krg to supply at least 230,000 barrels per day to somo for export, generates revenues primarily in usd, which must be repatriated and converted at a stable, internationally recognized rate to fund federal budget obligations, thereby necessitating a revalued dinar on forex to avoid black-market distortions and ensure seamless capital inflows. without this forex accessibility, somo's marketing of kurdish oil comparable in quality to russian grades and targeted at european buyers would face pricing inefficiencies, as hedging contracts require a liquid dinar pair to lock in profits against iqd fluctuations, directly tying the deal's totality to a year-end revaluation for credible global supply chain participation.

defi has unlocked incredible freedom anyone, anywhere, can trade without asking permission. but freedom came with friction: high gas, failed transactions, and invisible mev bots constantly skimming value from traders. most people got used to it. some even call it â€œthe cost of being on chain.â€ veloradex looks at it differently. what if trading didnâ€™t have to feel like a fight? what if instead of battling against the system, the system was designed to compete for you? thatâ€™s the essence of intent-based trading. instead of telling the blockchain exactly how to execute a trade, you just state your intent â€œi want to swap x for y at the best price.â€ from there, a network of solvers competes to give you the best outcome. the shift is powerful: gasless execution â†’ you only pay when a trade succeeds, no wasted eth. mev protection â†’ bots donâ€™t get to front-run your moves. sharper prices â†’ solvers battle each other to fill your order efficiently. real traction â†’ $12b+ quarterly volume and 18k+ active traders show itâ€™s more than theory. hereâ€™s where the curiosity kicks in: if intent-based systems already make swaps safer and cheaper, what happens when this expands? imagine borrowing, lending, or cross-chain swaps where you never worry about bridges, failed tx, or hidden costs just your intent, and the system delivers. thatâ€™s what veloradex is quietly building toward. itâ€™s not just about making swaps better. itâ€™s about reshaping defi around the user instead of the machine. so the real question isnâ€™t whether intent-based defi works itâ€™s how soon before it becomes the new standard. zonauang sstvi zeenunew gaza trump

kurdistan salaries suspended pending oil. cabinet meeting ends without decision oil exports from the kurdistan region have been a contentious issue since 2014, when the krg began selling crude independently of baghdad. i've traded crude oil for 20 years and have watch this drama unfold for years, so this is not surprising. disputes over revenue sharing and federal oversight over krg oil have repeatedly led to disruptions in exports. an informed source revealed, on tuesday (september 16, 2025), that the council of ministers concluded its meeting without making a decision regarding the disbursement of salaries to employees of the kurdistan region. the source explained to baghdad today that the government is linking salary funding to the implementation of the oil export agreement, stressing that this condition remains an obstacle to the release of funds allocated to the region's employees. the kurdistan region's employee payroll has been complicated for years by disputes between baghdad and erbil over oil exports and financial revenues. the federal government asserts that salary disbursements are linked to the implementation of oil agreements and ensuring revenues reach the public treasury. meanwhile, the regional government demands that salaries be disbursed without any preconditions, as this is a legal entitlement for its employees.

daily oil production to iraq. in return, baghdad is obliged to allocate one trillion iraqi dinars to the kurdistan region. clickbaiters told you over an over it's delay was for a new rate: total bs the delay was because baghdadi and kurdistan have have different models for contracts with international oil companies (iocs) 1. federal gov. is a service contracts model for iocs government hires (pays the money upfront) to iocs as contractors to explore, develop, and produce oil. iocs are paid a fixed fee plus a share of production for their services. 2. krg is a production sharing contracts model iocs act as partners, funding all exploration and development risks. they receive a share of the produced oil (after cost recovery) as profit, with the government taking the remainder. the fed gov. service contracts prioritize government control while krg pscs production sharing contracts model with no state outlay upfront and profit sharing. baghdad pivot toward psc-like elements (as in this deal) reflects necessity.its liquidity crunch makes the krg's model more viable, to read full article the recent agreement between the kurdistan regional government (krg) and baghdad on the resumption of oil exports has been hailed as a landmark achievement for the kurdistan region, with potential ripple effects across iraqâ€™s energy policy, according to energy and oil contracts expert dilshad muwani, muwani emphasized that the deal represents not only an economic and political win for erbil but also a structural shift in how iraq manages its oil sector. key provisions of the agreement under the deal, the kurdistan region will supply its daily oil production to iraq. in return, baghdad is obliged to allocate one trillion iraqi dinars to the kurdistan region. muwani stressed that this arrangement strengthens the krgâ€™s position: â€œthe kurdistan region is the major winner in this agreement. iraq is effectively forced to provide budgetary support to the region in exchange for access to its oil production.â€ baghdadâ€™s shift toward production sharing the agreement underscores iraqâ€™s worsening cash crisis, which has constrained its ability to sustain traditional oil service contracts. under the service contract model, the iraqi government pays upfront for exploration and production costs and later compensates companies with a portion of the extracted oil. however, muwani noted that iraq no longer has the liquidity to maintain this system: â€œiraq does not have enough cash to invest in oil fields and drill new wells. it cannot pursue service contracts in which the government pays the cost of extraction and then rewards companies with oil.â€ by contrast, the kurdistan region has long relied on production sharing contracts (pscs), in which foreign companies cover exploration and drilling costs in exchange for a negotiated share of production. this model suited the krg in its early years, when it lacked robust oil infrastructure and sufficient investment capital. now, faced with a fiscal crunch, baghdad appears to be shifting closer to the kurdistan model. â€œdue to its liquidity crisis, iraq is forced to resort to production-sharing mechanisms. this reduces the financial burden on the federal government and encourages foreign companies to invest without baghdad having to allocate large amounts of cash,â€ muwani explained. implications for iraqâ€™s energy policy analysts argue that the agreement could mark a turning point for iraqâ€™s broader oil strategy. the deal not only ensures a steady flow of revenue for the kurdistan region but also signals baghdadâ€™s willingness to embrace new contractual models. muwani underlined the significance of this shift:â€œthe agreement between the kurdistan region and baghdad is not only an economic and political achievement for erbil, but it will also reshape iraqâ€™s oil policy. iraqâ€™s move toward co-production contracts represents an important transformation that requires deeper research to assess its long-term impact.â€ the alignment of federal oil policy with the krgâ€™s psc framework could also pave the way for greater stability in investor relations, potentially making iraq more attractive to international energy companies seeking predictable, profit-sharing arrangements. the resumption of oil exports from the kurdistan region represents more than a budgetary lifeline. it underscores baghdadâ€™s growing reliance on the production-sharing model pioneered by the krg, driven by its own financial crisis. if managed wisely, this shift could stabilize iraqâ€™s energy sector, attract foreign investment, and redefine federal-regional relations in the oil industry. still, the long-term implicationsâ€”both political and economicâ€”remain uncertain. as muwani concludes, the agreement â€œdraws a new map for oil relations in iraqâ€ and requires careful policy planning to maximize benefits for both baghdad and erbil while ensuring regional energy stability.

delivered a statement that could redefine iraqâ€™s energy map. he confirmed that the federal government in baghdad and international oil companies (iocs) operating in the region have reached a broad understandingâ€”one that may soon unlock the long-stalled resumption of kurdish oil exports. geopolitical context for 18 months, kurdish crude has been absent from international markets after exports through turkeyâ€™s ceyhan pipeline were suspended in march 2023. the freeze has drained more than \$30 billion from iraq and the kurdistan region, tightening fiscal space, reducing investment flows, and weakening confidence in the countryâ€™s oil sector. the new understanding marks a step toward reconciling iraqâ€™s competing power centers: baghdadâ€™s federal control and erbilâ€™s autonomous energy policy. if implemented, it would not only restore vital revenues but also stabilize relations with ankara, which has been eager to see the pipeline reopened under a clear legal framework. banking and fiscal dimensions beyond oil, barzani underscored erbilâ€™s cooperation with baghdad on budget and salary disputes, stressing that â€œno obstacles have ever been createdâ€ from kurdistanâ€™s side. a july deal already set terms: erbil agreed to transfer 230,000 barrels per day to somo and remit 120 billion iraqi dinars in non-oil revenues, in return for federal salary disbursements. yet delays persistâ€”civil servants only received june salaries in september, while july and august remain unpaid. such gaps undermine public trust and highlight the urgent need for more predictable federal transfers and financial discipline. currency and economic outlook should oil exports resume, iraqâ€™s macroeconomic landscape could shift significantly. restoring over 400,000 barrels per day from the kurdistan region would inject billions in foreign exchange into iraqâ€™s reserves, strengthen the central bank of iraqâ€™s ability to defend the dinar, and relieve pressure on the parallel market. internationally, investors would interpret the breakthrough as a sign of political maturity and institutional coherence, potentially accelerating iraqâ€™s bid for greater global financial integration, including wto accession and deeper ties with ifis. outlook barzaniâ€™s remarks signal more than a technical oil dealâ€”they represent a potential reset of baghdadâ€“erbil relations. if baghdad delivers on salary payments and iocs receive payment guarantees, the long-awaited flow of kurdish oil could resume within weeks. this would send a powerful message: iraq is ready to move past old disputes and harness its full energy potential for national stability and regional influence. for the kurdistan region, it would mean fiscal breathing room and renewed faith in partnership with baghdad. for iraq as a whole, it would mean reclaiming lost revenues, strengthening its currency base, and demonstrating to global markets that cooperation, not fragmentation, defines its future. melaniastasia romanov

boom! krg, baghdad, oil firms sign deal to resume kurdistan oil exports erbil â€“ the kurdistan regional government (krg), iraqâ€™s ministry of oil, and oil-producing companies have signed a trilateral agreement to resume oil exports from the kurdistan region, basnews has learned. the agreement, signed monday afternoon in erbil, clears the way for the re-export of kurdish crude through turkeyâ€™s ceyhan port after more than two years of suspension. the deal is expected to be formally announced by prime minister mohammed shia al-sudani at tuesdayâ€™s iraqi council of ministers meeting, where further details will be released. earlier in the day, a technical delegation from iraqâ€™s state-run north oil company visited erbil to finalize export procedures. the delegation held a four-hour meeting with the krgâ€™s ministry of natural resources, paving the way for the dealâ€™s conclusion. under the agreement, the kurdistan region will hand over 230,000 barrels of crude per day to the state organization for marketing of oil (somo), while retaining 50,000 barrels for domestic consumption. exports will flow to ceyhan via the north oil company. krg spokesperson peshawa hawramani had told basnews on monday that such a deal was imminent, stressing that it would remove obstacles to the transfer of federal salaries to kurdistan region employees. oil exports from the kurdistan region through ceyhan were halted in march 2023 following a ruling by the international chamber of commerceâ€™s court of arbitration in paris. the court found that turkey had violated a 1973 pipeline agreement by allowing erbil to independently export crude without baghdadâ€™s consent between 2014 and 2018, ordering ankara to pay $1.5 billion in damages to iraq. although turkey has appealed the ruling, it has signaled readiness to reopen the pipeline once baghdad and erbil reach an internal settlement. the suspension has cost the krg billions of dollars in revenue and deepened its reliance on federal budget transfers to cover public sector salaries. the resumption of exports is seen as a breakthrough for both erbil and baghdad, potentially easing long-standing disputes over oil and revenue sharing while reassuring international oil companies invested in the kurdistan region.

revealing its role, washington: the baghdad-kurdistan agreement will enhance regional energy security us secretary of state mike rubio revealed on thursday washington's role in the baghdad-kurdistan region agreement to resume oil exports, stressing that it will enhance "regional security." "we welcome the announcement that the government of iraq has reached an agreement with the kurdistan regional government and international companies to reopen the iraq-turkey pipeline, an agreement facilitated by the united states that will deliver tangible benefits to americans and iraqis alike," rubio said in a press statement. he added, "we commend the decisive efforts of iraqi prime minister mohammed shia al-sudani and senior iraqi government officials, as well as kurdistan regional government prime minister masrour barzani and senior krg officials, to achieve this progress." he continued, "this agreement will strengthen the mutually beneficial economic partnership between the united states and iraq, encourage a more stable investment environment across iraq for american companies, enhance regional energy security, and strengthen iraqi sovereignty." iraqi prime minister mohammed shia al-sudani announced thursday evening that he had reached an oil agreement with the kurdistan region, describing it as "historic." the federal ministry of oil indicated that the agreement is the result of ongoing efforts over the past months to establish clear mechanisms to ensure smooth export flows and transparency in revenues . it's worth noting that the kurdistan regional government's ministry of natural resources, the iraqi ministry of oil, and oil companies signed a tripartite agreement last monday, paving the way for the resumption of the export of kurdistan region oil via the ceyhan pipeline. kurdistan region oil exports were halted on march 25, 2023, following an international arbitration ruling requiring turkey not to allow the region's oil exports without the approval of the federal government in baghdad . since then, shipments of an estimated 450,000 barrels per day have been disrupted, including 400,000 from the kurdistan region and 50,000 from the northern kirkuk fields. this disruption has resulted in daily financial losses exceeding $30 million, according to unofficial estimates.

help me congratulate dr. phoutvichay linsomphou on the successful completion of his phd under my supervision. his dissertation examines how infrastructure connectivity, trade integration, and renewable energy development shape economic growth in asean countries, filling a major gap in the tradeâ€“growth literature. unlike studies that focus narrowly on trade volume or rely on growth models with assumptions ill-suited for low-income economies, his research highlights the importance of aligning factor-intensive trade with connectivity modes. using a dual frameworkâ€”a modified jones (1996) semi-endogenous model and an augmented solow modelâ€”it shows that growth in asean depends not on openness alone but on the interaction of trade, infrastructure, and renewable energy. the findings are especially striking for countries like lao pdr, where renewable energy intensity and human capital amplify the growth effects of capital-intensive trade when supported by efficient transport systems. as a supervisor, it is deeply rewarding to witness such scholarly achievement, which also reminds me with gratitude of the guidance once given by my own phd mentor.

around $220, pushed to $350, then spent over four months consolidating between $300 and $350. this is a textbook pattern, a big decline, big advance off a low, followed by a long consolidation. this allowed all key moving averages to tighten on the daily and weekly timeframe. the most important technical aspect of this trade is the volatility contraction. may to september volatility slowly decreased and price action tightened. if you start in may, the pullbacks got less severe as the base progressed. from the peak in may to the breakout in september, the declines were: -26%, -20%, -13%, -10%, -9%. this is textbook, less sellers continued to show up as the base progressed. from contraction comes expansion. the narrative and fundamental aspect of the trade is what juiced it further. 1. venezuelaâ€™s oil wealth venezuela has the largest proven oil reserves in the world, even more than saudi arabia. oil makes up about 95% of venezuelaâ€™s exports and is the backbone of its economy. 2. u.s. sanctions & economic collapse in the 2010s, the u.s. imposed heavy sanctions on venezuelaâ€™s oil industry (especially on state oil company pdvsa). these sanctions were meant to pressure nicolÃ¡s maduroâ€™s government. the result: venezuela was cut off from the u.s. financial system, couldnâ€™t sell oil freely, and its currency collapsed. this triggered hyperinflation, with basic goods costing millions of bolÃ­vars. 3. china steps in while the u.s. tried to choke venezuela economically, china and russia stepped in as lifelines. china has loan-for-oil deals with venezuela, meaning venezuela sends crude in exchange for chinese financing. in recent years, china buys much of venezuelaâ€™s sanctioned oil at a discount, rerouting it through middlemen or blending it to hide its origin. 4. why the u.s. wants it the u.s. still wants access to venezuelan oil because: itâ€™s close geographically (cheap transport compared to middle east). it could help stabilize oil prices and reduce dependence on opec and hostile states. american refineries are built to process venezuelaâ€™s heavy crude. 5. the big picture venezuelaâ€™s crisis wasnâ€™t just from â€œbad socialismâ€ or â€œmismanagementâ€ â€” u.s. sanctions crushed its ability to sell oil legally. china filled the gap, securing cheap energy while building political influence in latin america. now the u.s. is reconsidering its stance, since blocking venezuela only pushed it deeper into chinaâ€™s orbit.
